I think we need to discuss the following steps somehow:

* Agree on the 3 level approach (landuse/landcover/amenity&leisure)
This includes the impact of landcover on the natural, surface & building keys. They all represent some "cover"

* Define the possible values for Belgium with photo's and videoclips. e.g. what's the difference between landuse=meadow and natural=wetland;wetland=wet_meadow ?

* "Borders". Where does landuse/landcover/A&L end, how does it work together with things such as ways, waterways, fences, & hedges
What about overlapping landuse/landcover ?
Yep. Let me define this in other words:
1) Tagging land-use/land-cover/natural features: what are the possible combination/exclusion?

I always like to turn things into little projects. How about we make a maproulette task to fix wood=* to modern tagging? There's quite a few left in belgium: http://overpass-turbo.eu/s/vto
I "hate" to participate in that type of projects, as they are only based on aerial imagery.

Hi. As I often find large mistakes in OSM caused by pure arm-chair mapping, I'd say first that I also don't like this kind of task. But on the other hand, I support this task (updating forest by fixing wood=* and adding leaf_type=* and leaf_cycle=*) because you can't really make big errors with that. To me classifying roads, or even drawing buildings needs much more terrain knowledge that interpreting forests from aerial imagery. Also, it is always better than running an algorithm on the deprecated wood=* tags. And I think persisting errors like deprecated tags does not serve OSM. I've heard several times people wondering why deprecated tags are not simply updated (for instance power=sub_station --> substation!).
BTW, I'll update a little bit the wiki page today. Let me know what do you think afterward!

content.body: About overlapping, it depends a lot of your scale of mapping. To me, you can draw a big polygon for a 1000's ha forest and tag it with landuse=forest, and then superimpose water, some buildings (forest lodges). But when it comes to detailed mapping, then people prefer to make less abstraction...

in case of roads, I just gave them an assumed width. But yes, if you need something more exact, that is lacking. On the scale of Belgium though, that is totally marginal compared to the huge holes in landuse mapping in city centers and some parts of Wallonia
Screen Shot 2018-01-29 at 10.48.48.png
it's just that it so inconsistent.

nr 40 is in its own residential area, 38 & 45 not. Why ? 45 might have been built after the mapping was done.

Another mistake I often notice is that forest areas are always bigger than they should be. it's never mapped as the bottom of the tree, always where the top (or even shadows) reach (at least in Flanders)
Here's another example of where things go wrong
DSC_6910.jpg

always hard to make decent landuse/landcover pictures. While there are a lot of smaller trees behind the bushes in the foreground, the landuse is meadow imho, though with a lot of trees on it, that I would prefer not the map separately.
The problem with the "forest that is too wide" is also seen for tree rows. The armchair mapper takes the complete area covered by the leafs (way wider than the trunk of the tree) as forest.
I think it's called "crown", not ?

About the residential land-use, to me it is adapted to "large-scale" mapping. When it comes to detailed mapping, you can use leisure=garden, parking, and plenty of other stuffs. So this kind of features should definitely overlap, with landuse=residential for delineating "urbanized" environment.

I more or less understand what you mean by urbanized environment.
I still have problems to apply that rule consistently
Sure! that's why I put "ubanized" in quotation marks: this is highly subjective!
Also, in OSM I think we forgot that mapping is making an abstraction of reality. For instance, do we include a hedge inside the meadow or not. It depends on your definition of meadow, but to me, yes.
To come back to you remark that you can always see on aerial imagery whether a forest is needleleaved or broadleaved. Can you easily spot mixed forests ?
Ahh, it would be nice to have a collection of screenshots to help with interpretaion

Mixed forests: in Wallonia, most of forest are mapped as mixed because they are not sufficiently polygonized in their different parts. Of course if you digitalize a forest at a super high resolution with each tree crown a polygon, there will not have any mixed forest anymore ;-)

I try to stick to leaving 'what's public road' outside of landuse = residential and other landuse polygons, and the lack of a landuse polygon ends up 'shaping' the areas that are public domain. But you can go with mapping the area's of the public domain used for roads (as GRB does), or you can go with landcover = asphalt / concrete to show the physical occurence of the roads. It's all very different approaches
different approaches, but not excluding one another.

content.body: The key problem I have with landuse = grass is that's is used ALOT on top of other landuses. Personally, I'm in favor of landcover aswell to avoid the conflicts, and ideally 'landuse' and 'landcover' create a full cover  independently of eachother.
But It's such a shame 'landcover' doesn't render currently, and because of that people resort to 'hidden' alternatives/workarounds like natural = * or leisure = * etc..

i think that one of the problems here is that landuse/landcover/several leisure/amenity are seen as "fill the map"
there are not a lot  of data consumers (or maybe none at all =) that actually need the finer detail of that information. For most people it's fine that the map shows trees/grass is some green shades, and they do not care whether that is caused by natural=wood, landuse=village_green or something else.

And from a beginners perspective: I've snapped leisure = park polygons to landuse = residential outlines, but there's no actual reason to do so as it's technically two unrelated things.
Somethings I worry about a bit: What if landuse and landcover boundaries legitimately match? That gives validation warnings for two exact same objects, no?

I have been thinking on the way home. Since landcover & landuse should both cover the whole world, it is impossible to create a map that shows both.
So instead of forcing landcover tags on the standard map, we need a clone that does not render landuse, but only landcover. Then you can put both maps next to one another and see e.g. where landcover=trees falls together with landuse=residential, or forest, or recreational.

The problem is that with overlapping landuse, the data consumers (i.e. a researcher for example) can't generaly use it realisticly as most of the time, the landuse analysis are made at large scale and he don't want to check each overlap to see which one is most logical for him. A landuse layer without overlap of landuse tags is probably better, and that's generally the main criticism about our landuse data which is mostly unusable for them (from what i heard from friend doing those researchs). It is not really difficult to get right here, just choose 1 (ONE) main landuse for each place (and i mean by landuse, also the different other tag that are in fact landuse like leisure=park).

Maybe make a list of these tag that are landuse posibilities and should mostly not overlap with each other. Then make the same for landcover, and here we go. I don't find it problematic as in most case, it is just changing a tag (like landuse=grass to landcover=grass or landuse=meadow or leisure=park or ... depending on what make most sense) and it can even be an improvement of the representation as a lot of people use landuse=grass as a general tag (like highway=path) when they don't know what it is.  What are the good or bad side of these ideas for you ? As i'm for it, i'm certainly blind to some downside ! :p

The main problem to create single "landuse" areas, is that you have to cut out the area from a larger one. That means:

* split the larger one in smaller pieces
* or, create a multipolygon
* or, replace the previously created multipolygon with smaller polygons. This is the most time consuming scenario.

that's why we end up with overlapping landuse on large residential areas. I haven't seen it used that often outside towns. 

I'm certainly interested to learn how one can convert a multi-polygon into several smaller polygons in an easy/fast way.

Lionel makes an interesting point about not just looking at it as 'landuse' and 'landcover' each ideally generating a full cover ,but the set of tags which aren 'hidden' forms of either aswell. Leisure = park is probably on of the prime examples on the matter.

And as for the 'smaller pieces': In earlier arguments, Glenn wondered why I tried to chop up residential blocks so small (excluding roads and all), but it's exactly doing that that lowers the threshold towards more detailed  definition of landuse.

If there's a chuck in between that's a park, or a an area within a building block still used as a meadow, you don't have to rely on the multipolygons with inner and outer relations, as the landuse generally touches at least one outline of the block...
why not have something like landuse=recreation on park ? Just a thought.

And as for the 'smaller pieces': In earlier arguments, Glenn wondered why I tried to chop up residential blocks so small (excluding roads and all), but it's exactly doing that that lowers the threshold towards more detailed  definition of landuse.

Won't work. Amenities are composed of different "landuses", amenities not only indicate a landuse, but group a number of facilities. Something you loose with only landuse
You are right, maybe we are trying to be too precise about it ? Does landuse need to be precise to the buildings or just give an idea of the use of a broader area ?

I'm still in favour of landuse/landcover/amenity. Those 3 levels express different things.
landcover = what's on the ground
landuse = what is the primary usage of the area
amenity = a grouping of a number of facility into something people know as pub, park, sport centre

Note that some those definitions can overlap with the current set of landuse/landcover/surface/natural/amenity/leisure and maybe others.

Furthermore, we will probably not be able to throw everything upside down, so the above model cannot be pushed through. Are there alternatives ? Maybe, but it can only be described  case-by-case, as one time you will have a landuse +natural, and another time leisure + surface.

I'm also in favour of being pretty precise (or at least have a model that can be used in the future to be precise). People are already mapping playgrounds in schools, grass sections in parks, etc. We should not roll that back imho.
Landuse should not be up to the building, I never mark a single small shop as retail area. I do it for shopping centres with parkings etc. Or even for car dealers.

I won't change the landuse of a single building (tourist info) in a park. But a garage where all the machinery for the maintenance is parked is probably bigger than a block of 10 smaller houses. So it deserves to be mapped separately.

content.body: I have added the issue of parcelisation in the wiki page https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/WikiProject_Belgium/Landuse (do not hesitate to edit this page !). To me, representing agricultural lands into parcels could be very useful for farming applications. But agricultural parcels can typically change of shape from years to years (farmers split and merge parcels depending on the crop, same for meadows sometimes). Actually every farmer in the EU has to digitalize this information every year to get the ACP subsidies. I know that in Flanders at least this information is anomysed and then released every year, but I don't know where and under which format.

Also, there is huge work for parcellising the forest patches into leaf_cycle=* and leaf_type=* and even species=*. Most of the time, this implies that you have to edit large multipolygons and transform them in a collection of smaller polygons, which is definitely not easy to do. The JOSM tool "contour merge" is your friend for this kind of task.

content.body:
```
(SELECT
    way, name, religion, way_pixels,
    COALESCE(aeroway, amenity, wetland, power, landuse, leisure, man_made, military, "natural", tourism, highway, railway) AS feature
  FROM (SELECT
      way, COALESCE(name, '') AS name,
      ('aeroway_' || (CASE WHEN aeroway IN ('apron', 'aerodrome') THEN aeroway ELSE NULL END)) AS aeroway,
      ('amenity_' || (CASE WHEN amenity IN ('parking', 'bicycle_parking', 'motorcycle_parking', 'university', 'college', 'school',
                                            'hospital', 'kindergarten', 'grave_yard', 'prison', 'place_of_worship', 'clinic', 'ferry_terminal')
                                            THEN amenity ELSE NULL END)) AS amenity,
      ('landuse_' || (CASE WHEN landuse IN ('quarry', 'vineyard', 'orchard', 'cemetery', 'residential', 'garages', 'meadow', 'grass',
                                            'allotments', 'forest', 'farmyard', 'farmland', 'greenhouse_horticulture',
                                            'recreation_ground', 'village_green', 'retail', 'industrial', 'railway', 'commercial',
                                            'brownfield', 'landfill', 'construction', 'plant_nursery', 'religious') THEN landuse ELSE NULL END)) AS landuse,
      ('leisure_' || (CASE WHEN leisure IN ('swimming_pool', 'playground', 'park', 'recreation_ground', 'common', 'garden',
                                            'golf_course', 'miniature_golf', 'picnic_table', 'fitness_centre', 'sports_centre', 'stadium', 'pitch',
                                            'track', 'dog_park') THEN leisure ELSE NULL END)) AS leisure,
      ('man_made_' || (CASE WHEN man_made IN ('works') THEN man_made ELSE NULL END)) AS man_made,
      ('military_' || (CASE WHEN military IN ('danger_area') THEN military ELSE NULL END)) AS military,
      ('natural_' || (CASE WHEN "natural" IN ('beach', 'shoal', 'heath', 'grassland', 'wood', 'sand', 'scree', 'shingle', 'bare_rock', 'scrub') THEN "natural" ELSE NULL END)) AS "natural",
      ('wetland_' || (CASE WHEN "natural" IN ('wetland', 'marsh', 'mud') THEN (CASE WHEN "natural" IN ('marsh', 'mud') THEN "natural" ELSE tags->'wetland' END) ELSE NULL END)) AS wetland,
      ('power_' || (CASE WHEN power IN ('station', 'sub_station', 'substation', 'generator') THEN power ELSE NULL END)) AS power,
      ('tourism_' || (CASE WHEN tourism IN ('attraction', 'camp_site', 'caravan_site', 'picnic_site') THEN tourism ELSE NULL END)) AS tourism,
      ('highway_' || (CASE WHEN highway IN ('services', 'rest_area') THEN highway ELSE NULL END)) AS highway,
      ('railway_' || (CASE WHEN railway = 'station' THEN railway ELSE NULL END)) AS railway,
      CASE WHEN religion IN ('christian', 'jewish', 'muslim') THEN religion ELSE 'INT-generic'::text END AS religion,
      way_area/NULLIF(!pixel_width!::real*!pixel_height!::real,0) AS way_pixels
    FROM planet_osm_polygon
    WHERE (landuse IS NOT NULL
      OR leisure IS NOT NULL
      OR aeroway IN ('apron', 'aerodrome')
      OR amenity IN ('parking', 'bicycle_parking', 'motorcycle_parking', 'university', 'college', 'school', 'hospital', 'kindergarten',
                     'grave_yard', 'place_of_worship', 'prison', 'clinic', 'ferry_terminal')
      OR man_made IN ('works')
      OR military IN ('danger_area')
      OR "natural" IN ('beach', 'shoal', 'heath', 'mud', 'marsh', 'wetland', 'grassland', 'wood', 'sand', 'scree', 'shingle', 'bare_rock', 'scrub')
      OR power IN ('station', 'sub_station', 'substation', 'generator')
      OR tourism IN ('attraction', 'camp_site', 'caravan_site', 'picnic_site')
      OR highway IN ('services', 'rest_area')
      OR railway = 'station')
      AND way_area > 0.01*!pixel_width!::real*!pixel_height!::real
    ORDER BY way_area DESC
  ) AS landcover
) AS features
```

(SELECT
    way, name, religion, way_pixels,
    COALESCE(aeroway, amenity, wetland, power, landuse, leisure, man_made, military, "natural", tourism, highway, railway) AS feature
  FROM (SELECT
      way, COALESCE(name, '') AS name,
      ('aeroway_' || (CASE WHEN aeroway IN ('apron', 'aerodrome') THEN aeroway ELSE NULL END)) AS aeroway,
      ('amenity_' || (CASE WHEN amenity IN ('parking', 'bicycle_parking', 'motorcycle_parking', 'university', 'college', 'school',
                                            'hospital', 'kindergarten', 'grave_yard', 'prison', 'place_of_worship', 'clinic', 'ferry_terminal')
                                            THEN amenity ELSE NULL END)) AS amenity,
      ('landuse_' || (CASE WHEN landuse IN ('quarry', 'vineyard', 'orchard', 'cemetery', 'residential', 'garages', 'meadow', 'grass',
                                            'allotments', 'forest', 'farmyard', 'farmland', 'greenhouse_horticulture',
                                            'recreation_ground', 'village_green', 'retail', 'industrial', 'railway', 'commercial',
                                            'brownfield', 'landfill', 'construction', 'plant_nursery', 'religious') THEN landuse ELSE NULL END)) AS landuse,
      ('leisure_' || (CASE WHEN leisure IN ('swimming_pool', 'playground', 'park', 'recreation_ground', 'common', 'garden',
                                            'golf_course', 'miniature_golf', 'picnic_table', 'fitness_centre', 'sports_centre', 'stadium', 'pitch',
                                            'track', 'dog_park') THEN leisure ELSE NULL END)) AS leisure,
      ('man_made_' || (CASE WHEN man_made IN ('works') THEN man_made ELSE NULL END)) AS man_made,
      ('military_' || (CASE WHEN military IN ('danger_area') THEN military ELSE NULL END)) AS military,
      ('natural_' || (CASE WHEN "natural" IN ('beach', 'shoal', 'heath', 'grassland', 'wood', 'sand', 'scree', 'shingle', 'bare_rock', 'scrub') THEN "natural" ELSE NULL END)) AS "natural",
      ('wetland_' || (CASE WHEN "natural" IN ('wetland', 'marsh', 'mud') THEN (CASE WHEN "natural" IN ('marsh', 'mud') THEN "natural" ELSE tags->'wetland' END) ELSE NULL END)) AS wetland,
      ('power_' || (CASE WHEN power IN ('station', 'sub_station', 'substation', 'generator') THEN power ELSE NULL END)) AS power,
      ('tourism_' || (CASE WHEN tourism IN ('attraction', 'camp_site', 'caravan_site', 'picnic_site') THEN tourism ELSE NULL END)) AS tourism,
      ('highway_' || (CASE WHEN highway IN ('services', 'rest_area') THEN highway ELSE NULL END)) AS highway,
      ('railway_' || (CASE WHEN railway = 'station' THEN railway ELSE NULL END)) AS railway,
      CASE WHEN religion IN ('christian', 'jewish', 'muslim') THEN religion ELSE 'INT-generic'::text END AS religion,
      way_area/NULLIF(!pixel_width!::real*!pixel_height!::real,0) AS way_pixels
    FROM planet_osm_polygon
    WHERE (landuse IS NOT NULL
      OR leisure IS NOT NULL
      OR aeroway IN ('apron', 'aerodrome')
      OR amenity IN ('parking', 'bicycle_parking', 'motorcycle_parking', 'university', 'college', 'school', 'hospital', 'kindergarten',
                     'grave_yard', 'place_of_worship', 'prison', 'clinic', 'ferry_terminal')
      OR man_made IN ('works')
      OR military IN ('danger_area')
      OR "natural" IN ('beach', 'shoal', 'heath', 'mud', 'marsh', 'wetland', 'grassland', 'wood', 'sand', 'scree', 'shingle', 'bare_rock', 'scrub')
      OR power IN ('station', 'sub_station', 'substation', 'generator')
      OR tourism IN ('attraction', 'camp_site', 'caravan_site', 'picnic_site')
      OR highway IN ('services', 'rest_area')
      OR railway = 'station')
      AND way_area > 0.01*!pixel_width!::real*!pixel_height!::real
    ORDER BY way_area DESC
  ) AS landcover
) AS features

content.body: you can see that in the end, leisure and others (man_made) is processed by landuse style (best explaination I can come up with now)
so, if you want to `hack` what is rendered on top of what, putting a higher `layer=X` tag on what you want on top should probably work in about 85% of the cases (some don't coalesce on layer)

content.body: which in the stylesheet is this :  `ORDER BY COALESCE(layer,0), way_area DESC`
content.formatted_body: which in the stylesheet is this : ORDER BY COALESCE(layer,0), way_area DESC

content.body: there's your default layer 0 btw

in addition:  ORDER BY COALESCE(layer,0), way_area DESC -> means the layer order is ascending , but the size of the are is descending.  so smaller is rendered on top of bigger and higher layer is rendered on top of lower layer values.

Essentially, I feel it's a crossover step: Where we are daydreamining of having a multitude of landcovers being possibly rendered, they all dump it into one same collection bin. If they do it often enough, they'll created leverage to have it renderend as green.

But if I'm interpreting correct, they general idea is to eventually ditch some of the 'landuse' tags on those polygons, and replace it with something like landcover = x. It's just sneaking in preparations to facilitate a later conversion.

Or perhaps they aren't being sneaky and all, but with landuse, landcover, and amenity/leasure tags, there's already sufficient types clogging up the tagging landscape without a need for yet another type that's a 'hidden landuse' tag.

those are all treated the same in most of the consumers like tile servers.   military areas, amenity areas,landuse and leisure=park for example, all are being processed as they are landuse through crafted DB queries by the style sheets (carto css case).  the list is longer than this..

Sitting in the train watching landuse pass by I realize that landuse is actually an osm perversion when it comes to making a map from it.  It conflicts with ground truth principles. A land can be used for nuclear testing but you aren't going to notice this while looking at the spot.  Landcover should be leading there.   In the map context that is, not saying the data isn't welcome in osm, but if you think it through, we color the map based on the goal rather than the situation of the land in question..

Alright, to add my 5 cents.
I have been mapping for a few years now. Landuse=residential is used for a residential area. I learned last week that it's better to use one great area for a village instead of use separate areas that don't contain any streets.
Of course, a residential area contains footpath areas, grass patches, areas with trees. So they should be able to overlap. You cannot "see" a residential area but it can be important on a map.
I have been using landuse=grass for small patches as well. How else are you supposed to map them? 
I never map overlaps between residential areas and agricultural areas (landuse=farmland). I have mapped overlaps however between residential areas and small commercial areas and farmyards.

content.body:
Hi Lievetje, thanks for bringing this up. A few questions/remarks:
- Where did you learn that you should map large areas for landuse=residential? There are different 'styles' for mapping this correctly. What I would advise: if you don't want to map everything in high detail, just make one large residential area, including e.g. streets and greenery. If you want to micromap an area, confine the landuse=residential to residential parcels (you can see them on the GRB base layer). That's also the advice on the [wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Tag:landuse%3Dresidential): "If you had access to land parcel data, you'd probably draw the ways with landuse=residential along the parcel edges, which are (mostly anyway) some distance away from the road centerline; i.e., behind the sidewalk."
- Often times, you do see the borders of a residential area / parcel. Hedges or fences are a good example, you can double check these borders with the parcel information in GRB
- landuse tags are used and also misused to map many different things, but in essence, these tags should describe "the primary use of land by humans" (from the [wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:landuse)). If you micromap patches of grass beside a road, I wouldn't let this overlap with a landuse=residential, but instead also micromap the residential areas. In general, I always try to avoid overlapping landuses (I believe editors also warn for this). For example, I don't see why you would let landuse=residential overlap with landuse=commercial or landuse=farmyard

If you are doubting on specific situations, do post a link. I'm sure other people will be happy to join the discussion

- In fact, Gpoilvet sent me a message last week: "Het is beter als je de residential area definieert voor heel het dorp Kieldrecht en niet aanduidt per huizenblok. Dit is een standaard die gehanteerd wordt en is praktisch voor ruimtelijk onderzoek. Alvast bedankt!"
But, when I see your point of view, I am again in doubt. I am indeed a micromapper that likes to add everything such as grass patches next to the sidewalk, hedges, fences, but also grass and trees in people's gardens. I am very willing to add multiple small residential areas but I am not sure how to add them when I'm also mapping people's gardens (as far as I can see them from the areal photography and live surveys).
